steps.title: Choose leaves that are still fresh and pliable.
steps.content: Choose leaves that are still fresh and pliable. Leaves that are dried will not work, as they'll snap and crumble when pressed or worked on. Make sure that the leaves are dry before using.

steps.title: Lay newspapers down to protect your work surface.
steps.content: Lay newspapers down to protect your work surface.

steps.title: Select a piece of paper for your leaf print.
steps.content: Select a piece of paper for your leaf print. Squeeze a little paint onto a small plate or palette.

steps.title: Paint the surface of the leaf with paint.
steps.content: Paint the surface of the leaf with paint. This is best done by placing the leaf on kitchen paper towel and painting over using a small paint roller suitable for craft projects. Make sure the entire leaf is covered. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Gently flip the leaf paint side down onto the paper.
steps.content: Gently flip the leaf paint side down onto the paper. Carefully but firmly press on the leaf to ensure that the entire leaf comes into contact with the paper. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Peel the leaf from the paper and you should have a printed mirror image of your leaf.
steps.content: Peel the leaf from the paper and you should have a printed mirror image of your leaf.

steps.title: Repeat with the same leaf and different leaves.
steps.content: Repeat with the same leaf and different leaves. The same leaf can be used up to six times before it ceases to leave an acceptable imprint. And by adding different sorts of leaves, you can build a pretty pattern or design for gift paper, cards, a painting, or any other paper craft project. [3] X Research source Add more leaves of different sizes and in different colors.

steps.title: Let the paintwork dry.
steps.content: Let the paintwork dry. Then frame or use your masterpiece for whatever purpose intended. [4] X Research source
